articles.headline: Medicare Widens Drugs It Accepts for Cancer
articles.snippet: With little public debate, Medicare has expanded its coverage for cancer treatments lacking F.D.A. approval.
articles.abstract: With little public debate, Medicare has expanded its coverage for cancer treatments lacking F.D.A. approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: Medicare, with little public debate, has expanded its coverage of drugs for cancer treatments not approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Barclays to Write Down £8 Billion, but Asks for No Help
articles.snippet: After investors punished its stock last week, Barclays attempted to restore trust in its earnings, saying it did not need fresh capital.
articles.abstract: After investors punished its stock last week, Barclays attempted to restore trust in its earnings, saying it did not need fresh capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The banking giant Barclays — like the British government whose bailout money it has spurned — faces a crisis of confidence among investors who are reluctant to take the word of anyone, banker or politician, at face value.

articles.headline: Teaching Teenagers About Harassment
articles.snippet: Digital harassment has gotten to be such a problem that it’s now the focus of a campaign from the Advertising Council.
articles.abstract: Digital harassment has gotten to be such a problem that it’s now the focus of a campaign from the Advertising Council.
articles.lead_paragraph: This month, three teenage girls, students at Greensburg Salem High School in Greensburg, Pa., were charged with disseminating child pornography.

articles.headline: Smoking Ban Hits Home. Truly.
articles.snippet: A strict antismoking law in a city in Silicon Valley has effectively banned lighting up in all apartment buildings.
articles.abstract: A strict antismoking law in a city in Silicon Valley has effectively banned lighting up in all apartment buildings.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELMONT, Calif. — During her 50 years of smoking, Edith Frederickson says, she has lit up in restaurants and bars, airplanes and trains, and indoors and out, all as part of a two-pack-a-day habit that she regrets not a bit. But as of two weeks ago, Ms. Frederickson can no longer smoke in the one place she loves the most: her home.

articles.headline: F.D.R’s Example Offers Lessons for Obama
articles.snippet: In the 1930s, President Franklin D. Roosevelt calmed Americans but had difficulty creating jobs.
articles.abstract: In the 1930s, President Franklin D. Roosevelt calmed Americans but had difficulty creating jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1933, as today, a new president stepped into the White House, vowing change and decisive action at a time when a banking crisis posed a grave threat to the nation’s economy.

articles.headline: Layoffs Spread to More Sectors of the Economy
articles.snippet: Companies across the board are resorting to mass job cuts, suggesting that employers expect a long downturn.
articles.abstract: Companies across the board are resorting to mass job cuts, suggesting that employers expect a long downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: Furloughs, wage reductions, hiring freezes and shorter hours simply did not do enough. A year into this recession, companies across the board are resorting to mass job cuts.

articles.headline: In India, Clues Unfold to a Fraud’s Framework
articles.snippet: As investigators seek a clearer picture of Satyam’s accounting, many wonder whether its executives had help.
articles.abstract: As investigators seek a clearer picture of Satyam’s accounting, many wonder whether its executives had help.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  How did B. Ramalinga Raju, the chairman of one of India’s largest information technology companies, carry out the biggest financial fraud in this country’s history? Apparently it does take a village.

articles.headline: For Pfizer, a Big Deal and a Test
articles.snippet: Layoffs, falling stock and slim dividends leave Pfizer little to cheer about one day after the $68 billion megamerger with Wyeth.
articles.abstract: Layoffs, falling stock and slim dividends leave Pfizer little to cheer about one day after the $68 billion megamerger with Wyeth.
articles.lead_paragraph: After announcing the $68 billion megamerger with Wyeth on Monday morning, Pfizer’s chief executive, Jeffrey B. Kindler, did not have much time to celebrate.

articles.headline: The Titans Take It on the Chin
articles.snippet: The Masters of the Universe are falling on hard times too, at least by their own gilded standards.
articles.abstract: The Masters of the Universe are falling on hard times too, at least by their own gilded standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many ordinary Americans are losing their jobs and savings because of the debacle on Wall Street.
